report_title: Office Stationery Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: The office stationery manufacturing industry in the US has been contending with the trend toward digitalization, leading to a decrease in demand for paper products and hampering growth. The pandemic further accelerated the reliance on electronic communication and business, resulting in declines in demand. Despite increased business activity and consumer spending before and after the pandemic, the industry's revenue has contracted at an expected CAGR of 3.9% to $5.9 billion through the end of 2024, including a 0.7% drop in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Plummeting demand for stationery products has forced companies to consolidate, implement automation and focus on specialty or niche markets.
As the internet accessibility grows for the average person, the percentage of business conducted online has skyrocketed.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Paper Products Face Heavy Environmental Backlash
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Anti-logging campaigns and lobbyists protesting wood usage in paper production have contributed to environmental concerns among businesses and consumers, promoting paperless offices.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Companies Search for Favorable Conditions Abroad
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In the coming years, companies will globalize, partially abandoning the heavily saturated domestic market and moving toward low-production cost countries with growing markets.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Companies Focus on Products That Complement Internet Accessibility
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Increasing smartphone and computer use will enable rapid information dissemination without printing or writing on paper.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Downstream Markets Switch to Online Advertising
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry will plummet as the internet usurps print media in every aspect of life. Online advertising poses a significant threat to office stationery products, especially envelopes.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry process paper and paperboard to produce a variety of stationery products used for writing, printing, filing, mailing and similar
key_trends: Product quality and timely delivery are key aspects of competition.
Successful manufacturers must cultivate a solid reputation to secure contracts.
Companies must readily adapt to shifting consumer preferences.
Companies must provide buyers with versatile product lines that complement new technology, like computers or inkjet printers.

The industry will contract as businesses and consumers switch to online advertising and messaging. Digital advertising campaigns can reach more people, crushing demand for office stationery products like envelopes.

Many manufacturers have turned to stronger markets or closed facilities entirely. Many emerging markets offer more favorable regulatory environments and less expensive production costs compared with the United States.
Successful manufacturers must innovate and introduce higher-quality and more versatile products.
Manufacturers face an increasingly hostile regulatory environment.
Profit has fallen as the industry struggles to compete with electronic alternatives.
Rising paper costs will continue to pressure office stationery manufacturers.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Industries that buy directly from manufacturers consume significant volumes of paper and stationery. Large volume demands from major corporations, including those within the printing industry, provide both parties with cost savings and favorable profit by eliminating retail and wholesale intermediaries.

Retailers struggle with nonessential business closures during the pandemic. Despite the trend toward digitalization, many businesses still rely on certain staple stationery products. Even so, the pandemic pushed more businesses online, sapping demand from this segment. A few large-scale companies, including Staples and Office Depot/OfficeMax, dominate stationery retailing. These companies have high purchasing power, enabling them to negotiate lower rates based on the volume of goods they buy. Also, many smaller, localized retail stores purchase products from manufacturers. Some can buy directly from the manufacturers, skipping wholesalers, increasing retailers' overall market share. The pandemic forced most nonessential retail businesses to shut down, slashing sales to the retail market.

Wholesalers combat wholesale bypass trends. As a crucial link between manufacturers and end users, wholesalers provide retailers an easy and effective distribution. To cut costs and attain more control over purchases, retailers increasingly purchase directly from manufacturers, bypassing distributors, negatively affecting this segment. Technological improvements, like online ordering, add to this trend, which have made ordering and distribution more cost-effective for retailers.

Other industries maintain strong demand. Other industries that purchase office stationery include government bodies, household consumers and restaurants, hotels and food services. These markets have displayed an inconsistent and declining need for stationary. While many companies are moving toward electronic alternatives, stationery is still widely used by government departments, schools and similar public organizations and will fuel growth as activity increases.

products_and_services.product_description: Die-cut office stationery struggles with paperless trends. Products in this segment include file folders, report covers, letters and paper rolls for business machines and cash registers. This segment relies on corporate and commercial business activity.

E-mail and online communication threaten envelopes. Buyers use envelopes for business and personal letters, direct mail and packages. Advertising mail accounted for more than 60.0% of mail received by households in 2021; the volume of letters has plummeted through 2023. Although commercial and personal letter envelope use has plummeted because of the growing use of electronic communication, online shopping and paper advertising developments have increased demand for shipping and direct-mail envelope production.

Paper supplies, stationery, writing tablets and related products shift to support technological developments. This segment includes bond paper, loose-leaf fillers, notebooks, paper pads, writing tablets, office paper for printing and photocopying and similar products. Within this segment, paper supplies for machines, like printing paper, have grown. Technological developments have led to the substitution of writing paper with printing paper. Even so, documents can now be circulated among employees electronically without the need for a hard copy; interoffice communication using paper products has decreased significantly.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: A large percentage of manufacturers sell stationery to end users through office supply stores. Activity in the Office Supply Store industry (IBISWorld report 45321) indicates changes in demand for office stationery products and prices. Office supply stores act as the retail outlets for manufactured stationery products, so as retail revenue increases, it reflects positively on demand for products from manufacturers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Chinese Imports Decline Amid Trade War
international_trade_points.trade_description: Despite the Chinese paper industry developing significantly over the past decade, the country's exports to the United States have fallen through 2023. The US government has levied tariffs against Chinese-produced office stationery and paper products amid its ongoing trade war. As tensions persist, Chinese imports will play a depressed role in trade markets.

The Mexican government's Prodeplan Initiative, which provides heavy subsidies toward the development of forest products, boosts the country's office stationery imports. The country also benefits from lower production costs than the United States, enabling Mexican manufacturers to sell products at lower prices than domestic goods.

international_trade_points.trade_title: A Strong US Dollar Slashes Exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: The rising value of the US dollar has made exports relatively more expensive on global markets, cutting demand for domestic products. As the dollar returns to its historical equilibrium, exports will rebound, growing throughout the outlook period.

international_trade_points.trade_title: United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) Drives the Export Market
international_trade_points.trade_description: Canada and Mexico account for the first- and second-largest share of exports, respectively. Both countries' high rates of exports are because they participate in the USMCA and proximity to the United States. Mexico, though, has reduced its intake of office stationery following the Prodeplan Initiative, reducing the country's reliance on imported paper products.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region has the highest percentage of establishments (around 35%) compared to its share of population (around 15%). This suggests that the Great Lakes region has a higher concentration of office stationery manufacturing establishments relative to its population. The document provides two reasons for this: 1) Proximity to major paper mills - The Great Lakes region has traditionally been one of the largest paper manufacturing areas in the United States. 2) Proximity to Canada - The region's proximity to Canada, the industry's largest export country, is an advantage.

Establishments heavily congregate in the region's key business and financial centers, like New York and Pennsylvania. Manufacturers take advantage of reduced shipping costs to retailers where many individuals and businesses purchase stationery products. Also, the region benefits from proximity to major ports that ship to European importers, like Italy and the Netherlands.

California has the highest percentage of establishments in the Office Stationery Manufacturing industry. The state provides access to major ports, like Los Angeles, where manufacturers can readily buy inexpensive paper imports and export products. The West has been expanding its population and labor force, enabling development growth across all industries in the region, including paper product manufacturing.

regulations_points.regulation_title: UPSTREAM REGULATIONS IMPACT OFFICE STATIONERY MANUFACTURERS
regulations_points.regulation_description: Most environmental and energy constraints only apply to the paper mills where office stationery manufacturers buy paper and paperboard. These regulations can influence the Office Stationery Manufacturing industry through its materials supply. The production of recycled paper stationery will expand with increased recycled paper production from paper mills. Strict compliance requirements in mills can swell the cost of paper used to produce stationery, limiting domestic companies' competitiveness in the global sphere.

The regulations applicable to the Office Stationery Manufacturing industry relate to general industrial and manufacturing activities, including the Clean Water Act (CWA), the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA), the Clean Air Act (CAA), the Cluster Rule and noise pollution control. Under the CWA and SWDA, the industry ensures that water and solid waste are discharged appropriately.

The industry is also subject to specific provisions relating to airborne pollution emissions. The CAA protects the nation's air resources for public health and welfare, limiting air pollutants like carbon monoxide, nitrous and sulfur oxides. The cluster rule regulates the release of water pollutant emissions of hazardous air pollutants from the pulp, paper and paperboard industries.

The US Code governs noise pollution. The law lists the types of industrial machinery considered and requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to monitor progress through a developed noise emission standard. Noise regulations consider the nature of the product, the best available technology and the cost of compliance with these standards.

While there are no rules on the number of recycled materials manufacturers must use for office stationery manufacturing, companies sometimes voluntarily participate in recycling, reducing energy consumption and using renewable energy. Through the American Forest and Paper Association, the paper industry set a goal to recover 70.0% of the paper consumed in the United States by 2020. Through 2023, the recycling paper rate has consistently reached or exceeded 63.0%.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs have remained steady despite the rising cost of paper. This is in part due to the ongoing wildfires in Canada, which have steered manufacturers toward domestic paper producers, allowing them to cut down on transportation costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Electronic Products Disrupt Office Stationery Products
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit has grown volatile over the past decade as buyers shift to electronic products and depend on computers and other electronic equipment in offices and at home. Companies have responded by cutting workforces and closing unprofitable facilities. Many companies have also introduced products that complement growing electronic products.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Companies Attempt to Lower Wage Costs With Automation
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Manufacturers require human labor for the proper operation of professional machinery. Despite mechanization efforts, companies still require labor for most operations, quality control and research and development (R&D) teams.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Manufacturers must secure skilled staff to operate the machinery and design the various stationery products. According to the National Association of Manufacturers, professionals trained in this area are increasingly challenging to find. Other required employees include floor staff, sales officers and staff for marketing, management and administrative employees.

Computerized systems use sensing and photo-detection devices to improve a machine's accuracy, efficiency, quality and lifespan. For companies with sufficient capital, these mechanization options have created major savings for labor costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Companies Keep Up With Consumer Trends
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Companies have innovated products that complement printers or other new technologies to stay relevant in a market controlled by online media and communication. For example, manufacturers have innovated the "Smart Guard Card" for security improvements and "Shimmer Print" for better exteriors. Also, many companies have focused on recycled paper products to appeal to eco-friendly buyers, encouraging new production methods.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Consumers Transition to Online Products and Services
volatility_points.volatility_description: Over the past decade, consumers and businesses have shifted to online methods of communication, organization and data filing. This trend has slashed demand for notebooks, envelopes, stationary and paper supplies. As the internet grows more accessible to the average consumer, individuals and businesses will shift to online services.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The Pandemic Hastened the Shift to Internet Services
volatility_points.volatility_description: During the pandemic, most businesses moved online, eliminating the need for office stationery products. For example, low levels of business activity and office closures decreased demand for register rolls and office supplies. Also, buyers often purchase stationery for special events, like business meetings or weddings. Many businesses also opt for online calendar invites instead of formal print invitations.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Less expensive imports have taken away market share from domestic stationery manufacturers, especially as the percentage of services conducted online has increased and made it easier for consumers to work directly with international manufacturers.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers sell a range of paper products, including stationery, tablets and writing pads, computer paper and envelopes

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: Many companies have looked to offshore operations overseas to cut costs through less costly labor and facility upkeep.

FAQs.question: Is your company located near important suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Many companies position themselves near paper mill manufacturers to cut down on the transportation of supplies and establish beneficial relationships.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology?
FAQs.answer: Computerized production systems have been widely adopted in recent years. Such systems use advanced sensing and photo-detection devices to adjust machinery settings and significantly improve the accuracy and quality of production and lifespan of the machinery.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: While some automation has occurred, this industry is relatively labor-intensive compared to other manufacturing industries.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations, such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Companies work with industry associations and the Environmental Protection Agency to stay on top of energy-efficiency standards and emerging regulations.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Companies work with associations, like the Envelope Manufacturers Association and Paper Industry Association Council, which organize events and link various customers along the supply chain.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit for the average manufacturer has increased because of effective cost-cutting measures, including shutting down underperforming facilities and cutting their workforce.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: Many manufacturers establish supply contracts with major clients, which may result in customers not paying on time because it is a renewal instead of a one-time purchase.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to pass on cost increases to members? What has been members' response to the increases?
FAQs.answer: When the price of paper or paperboard increases, manufacturers need to be able to charge more for the end product to cover rising cost pressures. This can be difficult in a market in which demand is falling.

FAQs.question: Which niches, if any, do you cater to? How do you keep track of the latest trends?
FAQs.answer: A degree of specialization within a company can provide access to niche markets, including direct-mail envelopes. This ability enables companies to reduce revenue volatility over time.

FAQs.question: Has your company developed export markets? If so, is there capacity to increase export volumes?
FAQs.answer: As the demand for stationery products declines in the United States, export markets provide new revenue opportunities for manufacturers.
